title: Timaru girl's smartphone explodes in the middle of school powhiri
text:
Timaru girl's smartphone explodes in the middle of school powhiri DAISY HUDSON Last updated 15:56, February 3 2017 JOHN BISSET/FAIRFAX NZ 
School assembly evacuated after students phone explodes. 
A Timaru teen says she was left speechless and shaking after her cellphone exploded in the middle of a school assembly. 
Five hundred Timaru Girls' High School students had to be evacuated from the school hall during a powhiri on Friday after Ella Broomhall's phone started billowing smoke. 
Samsung has initiated a full investigation into what it calls "an isolated incident". It follows controversy over faulty batteries in the Galaxy Note 7 model of Samsung's phones, which have been banned from a number of airlines, and a Christchurch man whose Samsung Trend exploded last month. Kelvin Jolly's leg was burnt and blistered after his smartphone exploded in his pocket while he was driving. JOHN BISSET/FAIRFAX NZ 
Ella Broomhall was "shocked" after her phone exploded during a school assembly. 
Broomhall, 17, said she didn't think much of it when she heard a "sizzling" noise during the assembly. 
READ MORE: 
"I heard a sizzling, buzzing noise, and I thought it was just someone's phone buzzing against the seat. JOHN BISSET/FAIRFAX NZ 
The phone was completely destroyed. 
"Then a big puff of smoke came out of my blazer pocket." 
She grabbed her phone and threw it onto a seat as her fellow students started running out of the building. 
"I was shaking, it felt like my heart stopped. I couldn't even talk." 
She had owned the Samsung Galaxy S6 phone for about two years and had never had any trouble with in the past. 
"It was very scary," she said. 
The phone was destroyed. 
A spokesman for Samsung New Zealand said customer safety was its highest priority, and the company was "deeply concerned" by the incident. 
"We have spoken to a family member of the customer to apologise and offer support. 
"We believe this is an isolated incident, as we are unaware of any known issues with the Galaxy S6; however we are taking the incident very seriously and will be conducting a full investigation into the matter." 
Hundreds of smartphone owners around the world sued Samsung Electronics after damage from spontaneous phone fires relating to the Galaxy Note 7 model. 
The S6 model was not previously believed to have had similar issues. 
Timaru Girls' High School principal Sarah Davis said the hall was evacuated and there was no danger to students. 
Staff had been debriefed and there would be a debrief with students as well, she said. 
"It was kind of alarming, it went bang. 
"The important thing is that Ella's safe." 
The powhiri was held on the tennis courts outside instead, she said. 
Anyone concerned about their Samsung phone can contact Samsung New Zealand's support line on 0800 726 786. - Stuff
